title: On Evolution-Based Models for Experimentation Under Interference
summary: This paper introduces an "evolution-based approach" for estimating population-level causal effects in networked systems where the exact interference (spillover) pathways are largely unobserved. Rather than recovering the network structure, the method characterizes how outcomes evolve across observation rounds in response to interventions, using a novel distributional difference-in-differences framework enabled by treatment randomization to compensate for missing network information.

title: Revolutionizing Glioma Segmentation & Grading Using 3D MRI - Guided Hybrid Deep Learning Models
summary: This paper introduces a novel hybrid deep learning framework for the accurate segmentation and grading of gliomas from 3D MRI scans. The model integrates a U-Net for precise tumor demarcation and a DenseNet-VGG classification network equipped with multihead and spatial-channel attention mechanisms. It achieved a 98% Dice coefficient for segmentation and 99% accuracy for classification, significantly outperforming traditional methods.

title: Geometric Confinement Reveals Scale-Free Velocity Correlations in Epithelial Cell Monolayer
summary: This paper investigates collective cell flows in MDCK epithelial monolayers under geometric confinement, revealing the emergence of scale-free spatial velocity correlations. These correlations follow a power law, challenging the notion of a single intrinsic correlation length and suggesting the monolayer behaves as a critical-like system capable of long-range information and stress propagation. The study also demonstrates that substrate properties (e.g., rigidity) and boundary conditions significantly influence flow organization and the distribution of mechanical markers like vimentin.

title: Fast 3D Ultrasound Localization Microscopy via Projection-based Processing Framework
summary: Three-dimensional ultrasound localization microscopy (ULM) enables comprehensive visualization of the vasculature, thereby improving diagnostic reliability. Nevertheless, its clinical translation remains challenging, as the exponential growth in voxel count for full 3D reconstruction imposes heavy c...

title: TAB-DRW: A DFT-based Robust Watermark for Generative Tabular Data
summary: This paper introduces TAB-DRW, an efficient and robust post-editing watermarking scheme for generative tabular data, aimed at addressing growing concerns about data provenance and misuse. TAB-DRW embeds watermark signals in the frequency domain using DFT and a novel rank-based pseudorandom bit generation. Experiments demonstrate its strong detectability, robustness against attacks, high data fidelity, and full support for mixed-type features.

title: Approximate Bayesian Computation Made Easy: A Practical Guide to ABC-SMC for Dynamical Systems with \texttt{pymc}
summary: Approximate Bayesian Computation with Sequential Monte Carlo (ABC-SMC) offers a powerful likelihood-free method for parameter inference in complex mechanistic models common in ecology, epidemiology, and life sciences where traditional likelihood functions are intractable. This tutorial provides a practical, example-driven introduction to implementing, diagnosing, and interpreting ABC-SMC analyses using Python and PyMC, addressing perceived adoption complexities for researchers.

title: Deep Learning-Based Multiclass Classification of Oral Lesions with Stratified Augmentation
summary: This research introduces a deep learning-based multiclass classification system designed to differentiate sixteen types of oral lesions, aiming to facilitate early diagnosis of oral cancer. It effectively addresses the challenges of limited and imbalanced medical datasets by employing stratified data splitting combined with advanced data augmentation and oversampling techniques. The proposed model achieved superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods, demonstrating the critical role of these data-handling strategies, especially for minority class recognition.

title: Enhanced Landmark Detection Model in Pelvic Fluoroscopy using 2D/3D Registration Loss
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework for enhancing automated landmark detection in pelvic fluoroscopy, addressing the limitation of existing methods that assume a fixed Antero-Posterior view. It proposes integrating a 2D/3D landmark registration loss into the training of a U-Net model to improve accuracy under realistic intra-operative conditions with variable patient pose. The study analyzes the performance differences between a baseline U-Net, a U-Net trained with this Pose Estimation Loss, and a fine-tuned version.

title: Some aspects of robustness in modern Markov Chain Monte Carlo
summary: This paper reviews the concept of robustness in modern Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms, which are crucial for approximating complex probability distributions. It specifically addresses scenarios where standard MCMC algorithms struggle due to two common pathologies: 'roughness,' characterized by rapid target distribution variation leading to numerical instability, and 'flatness,' where the distribution's barren landscape causes the algorithm to get lost. The work synthesizes existing algorithmic remedies for these issues and proposes future research directions to enhance MCMC reliability.

title: Machine Learning Approaches to Clinical Risk Prediction: Multi-Scale Temporal Alignment in Electronic Health Records
summary: This study introduces the Multi-Scale Temporal Alignment Network (MSTAN) to address challenges like temporal irregularity and multi-scale dynamic dependencies in Electronic Health Records (EHR) for clinical risk prediction. MSTAN employs a learnable temporal alignment mechanism and multi-scale convolutions to model both long-term trends and short-term fluctuations, demonstrating superior performance against mainstream baselines on public EHR datasets.

title: The Age-specific Alzheimer 's Disease Prediction with Characteristic Constraints in Nonuniform Time Span
summary: This study introduces an innovative methodology for age-specific Alzheimer's disease (AD) prediction using sequential MRI image generation, addressing challenges posed by irregular time-series inputs. It integrates quantitative metrics to maintain essential disease characteristics and an age-scaling factor to produce age-specific MRI images, significantly improving synthesis accuracy. The approach facilitates the prediction of advanced AD stages and achieved a peak Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) of 0.882 for long-term prognosis.

title: Self-Paced Learning for Images of Antinuclear Antibodies
summary: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework for the automated detection of Antinuclear Antibodies (ANA) from microscope images, a crucial but complex task in diagnosing autoimmune disorders. The framework specifically addresses the challenges of multi-instance, multi-label (MIML) learning inherent in ANA patterns, achieving state-of-the-art performance by integrating an instance sampler, a probabilistic pseudo-label dispatcher, and self-paced learning components.

title: Lost in Time? A Meta-Learning Framework for Time-Shift-Tolerant Physiological Signal Transformation
summary: This paper introduces ShiftSyncNet, a novel meta-learning framework that addresses the critical problem of temporal misalignment in multimodal physiological signal transformation (e.g., PPG to ABP). By employing a bi-level optimization approach with a transformation network and a time-shift correction network, ShiftSyncNet automatically learns and applies Fourier phase shifts to align supervision signals, significantly improving the accuracy of deriving clinically meaningful information from non-invasive data. Experiments show it outperforms strong baselines by substantial margins across various datasets.

title: A Dynamic Anti-Equinus Orthosis with Electromyography Sensor for Neuromuscular Rehabilitation
summary: This study introduces EquiSay, a dynamic anti-equinus orthosis designed to improve ankle dorsiflexion and gait in patients with equinus foot, featuring an anterior elastic tension system and an integrated EMG sensor for real-time neuromuscular monitoring. To overcome limited EMG data, the system incorporates a U-Net based model for synthetic EMG generation and a predictive framework for automatic activation threshold calibration. Experimental results demonstrated improved dorsiflexion, increased patient satisfaction, and provided valuable clinical insights for rehabilitation planning.

title: Conversational no-code and multi-agentic disease module identification and drug repurposing prediction with ChatDRex
summary: ChatDRex is a novel conversational, multi-agent AI system designed to democratize network-based drug repurposing prediction by providing natural language access to complex bioinformatics analyses. It leverages the integrated NeDRex knowledge graph and specialized agents, enabling physicians and researchers without computer science expertise to identify disease modules and propose drug candidates. This system aims to accelerate the discovery of novel therapies and advance personalized medicine through efficient in silico predictions.

title: Anomaly Detection with Adaptive and Aggressive Rejection for Contaminated Training Data
summary: This paper introduces Adaptive and Aggressive Rejection (AAR), a novel method designed to robustly perform anomaly detection by handling contaminated training data. AAR dynamically identifies and excludes anomalies using modified z-scores and Gaussian Mixture Model-based thresholds, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods by 0.041 AUROC. This approach enhances the reliability of AI models in real-world applications, particularly in sensitive domains like healthcare.
domains: Medical Imaging (e.g., radiology, pathology for anomaly detection)
Diagnostic Support Systems (identifying rare conditions or atypical patterns)
Public Health Surveillance (identifying outbreaks or unusual patterns in health data)
Clinical Trial Data Analysis (flagging anomalous patient responses or data entries)

title: The Directed Prediction Change - Efficient and Trustworthy Fidelity Assessment for Local Feature Attribution Methods
summary: This paper introduces the Directed Prediction Change (DPC) metric to efficiently and deterministically assess the fidelity of local feature attribution methods, which is crucial for trustworthy AI explanations in high-stakes medical settings. DPC modifies the existing Prediction Change metric by incorporating perturbation and attribution direction, achieving a nearly tenfold speedup and eliminating randomness compared to Monte Carlo methods like Infidelity, while measuring the same underlying property. This enables holistic, computationally efficient, and reproducible evaluation of explainable AI (XAI) algorithms.

title: Stopping power monitoring during proton therapy by means of prompt gamma timing: first experimental results with a homogeneous phantom
summary: This paper introduces Spatiotemporal Emission Reconstruction from Prompt-Gamma Timing (SER-PGT) as a promising method to monitor proton therapy in real-time, providing crucial insights into particle range and stopping power. Initial experimental results, using a 226.9 MeV proton beam on a homogeneous phantom at sub-clinical intensity, demonstrate the feasibility of SER-PGT. The method achieved an 8% error in stopping power estimation and successfully identified range shifts with a 3 mm standard deviation.

title: SurgMLLMBench: A Multimodal Large Language Model Benchmark Dataset for Surgical Scene Understanding
summary: Recent advances in multimodal large language models (LLMs) have highlighted their potential for medical and surgical applications. However, existing surgical datasets predominantly adopt a Visual Question Answering (VQA) format with heterogeneous taxonomies and lack support for pixel-level segmentat...

title: Behavior-induced oscillations in epidemic outbreaks with distributed memory: beyond the linear chain trick using numerical methods
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model demonstrating that human behavioral adaptation to information about new infection cases, through a continuously distributed memory kernel, can independently drive sustained oscillations in epidemic outbreaks. Using advanced numerical methods, it shows these behavior-induced waves can occur even without typical drivers like demographics or waning immunity, providing insights into how memory parameters and baseline contact levels influence wave characteristics.

title: Learning Cell-Aware Hierarchical Multi-Modal Representations for Robust Molecular Modeling
summary: CHMR is a novel framework that addresses limitations in molecular modeling by jointly learning cell-aware, hierarchical multi-modal representations. It integrates molecular structures with cellular responses, capturing latent biological hierarchies via a tree-structured vector quantization module. This approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods on diverse molecular prediction tasks, demonstrating the benefit of biologically grounded, multi-modal learning for robust drug effect prediction.

title: Deformation-aware Temporal Generation for Early Prediction of Alzheimers Disease
summary: This paper introduces the Deformation-Aware Temporal Generative Network (DATGN) to automate the learning of brain morphological changes from MRI sequences for early Alzheimer's disease (AD) prediction. DATGN interpolates incomplete MRI sequences and generates future images consistent with disease progression, which, when integrated as synthetic data, significantly improves AD vs. NC and AD vs. MCI vs. NC classification accuracy. The method offers a novel approach to leveraging temporal imaging data for enhanced early diagnosis.

title: Interpretable Fair Clustering
summary: This paper introduces an interpretable and fair clustering framework that embeds fairness constraints directly into the structure of decision trees, addressing the interpretability gap in existing fair clustering methods. The proposed approach constructs decision trees that partition data equitably across protected groups, demonstrating competitive clustering performance, improved fairness, and robust handling of multiple sensitive attributes. A practical variant requiring no fairness hyperparameter tuning is also presented, enhancing the applicability of transparent and equitable clustering in high-stakes scenarios.

title: Aligning LLMs with Biomedical Knowledge using Balanced Fine-Tuning
summary: This paper introduces Balanced Fine-Tuning (BFT), an efficient post-training method designed to align Large Language Models (LLMs) with specialized biomedical knowledge by addressing limitations of current approaches like Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Reinforcement Learning (RL). BFT employs a novel two-layer weighting mechanism to stabilize gradients, prevent overfitting to sparse data, and adaptively enhance learning from hard samples. Experiments demonstrate that BFT significantly outperforms SFT in medical and biological reasoning tasks, enabling LLMs to acquire critical knowledge and support downstream biomedical predictions.

title: Long-Term Alzheimers Disease Prediction: A Novel Image Generation Method Using Temporal Parameter Estimation with Normal Inverse Gamma Distribution on Uneven Time Series
summary: This paper introduces T-NIG, a novel image generation method for long-term Alzheimer's Disease (AD) prediction that addresses the challenge of irregular time intervals in sequential brain imaging data. T-NIG estimates a temporal parameter within a Normal Inverse Gamma Distribution to model disease characteristic changes over time, enabling the generation of intermediate and future brain images for disease forecasting. The model achieves state-of-the-art performance in both short-term and long-term AD prediction, maintaining crucial disease-related characteristics despite uneven temporal data distribution.

title: AerialMind: Towards Referring Multi-Object Tracking in UAV Scenarios
summary: This paper introduces AerialMind, the first large-scale benchmark for Referring Multi-Object Tracking (RMOT) in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) scenarios, addressing the limitations of ground-level RMOT for comprehensive scene understanding. It also proposes HawkEyeTrack (HETrack), a novel method designed to enhance vision-language representation learning for improved perception in UAV environments, validated through experiments demonstrating the dataset's challenge and the method's effectiveness.

title: LungNoduleAgent: A Collaborative Multi-Agent System for Precision Diagnosis of Lung Nodules
summary: LungNoduleAgent is an innovative collaborative multi-agent system designed for precise diagnosis of lung nodules from CT scans, addressing limitations in current multimodal large language models regarding morphological description and medical expertise integration. It streamlines the diagnostic process through three sequential modules, demonstrating superior performance against existing models and highlighting the critical role of region-level semantic alignment and multi-agent collaboration.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Vision Transformer Learning Leveraging Lightweight Homomorphic Encryption in Medical AI
summary: This paper addresses the critical challenge of privacy in collaborative medical AI by proposing a novel federated learning framework that integrates Vision Transformers (ViT) with lightweight homomorphic encryption (HE). It secures multi-institutional histopathology classification by encrypting compact ViT CLS tokens, effectively preventing sensitive data reconstruction attacks while achieving significant communication efficiency and high diagnostic accuracy.

title: BUSTR: Breast Ultrasound Text Reporting with a Descriptor-Aware Vision-Language Model
summary: BUSTR proposes a novel multitask vision-language framework for automated breast ultrasound (BUS) report generation that overcomes the limitations of scarce paired image-report datasets and large language model hallucinations. It achieves this by generating reports from structured descriptors and radiomics features, learning descriptor-aware visual representations without direct paired supervision, and demonstrating improved natural language generation and crucial clinical efficacy metrics.

title: Stabilizing Fractional Dynamical Networks Suppresses Epileptic Seizures
summary: This paper introduces a novel method that stabilizes fractional dynamical networks, modeled from intracranial EEG (iEEG) data, to effectively suppress epileptic seizure activity. The approach successfully suppressed 34 out of 35 spontaneous episodes with a substantial 49% average amplitude reduction in simulated controlled signals, demonstrating the potential of fractional dynamics to characterize and control seizure-related brain states.

title: Fusion of classical and quantum kernels enables accurate and robust two-sample tests
summary: This paper introduces a novel hybrid statistical testing strategy, MMD-FUSE, which fuses classical and quantum kernels to improve two-sample tests, particularly for small and high-dimensional datasets. The approach enhances the Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) framework by combining the unique expressive power of quantum kernels with the domain-specific biases of classical kernels. Experiments on synthetic and real-world clinical datasets demonstrate that this hybrid method achieves superior test power and remarkable robustness compared to classical counterparts.

title: A deep learning model to reduce agent dose for contrast-enhanced MRI of the cerebellopontine angle cistern
summary: This study evaluated a deep learning (DL) model designed to restore high-quality contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI (T1ce) images of the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) cistern from simulated low-dose acquisitions. The model significantly improved image quality and lesion segmentation performance, allowing for accurate diagnostic characterization with only 10% to 30% of the standard contrast agent dose. This innovation holds promise for reducing gadolinium exposure in patients requiring MRI of the CPA.

title: Exploring Time-Step Size in Reinforcement Learning for Sepsis Treatment
summary: This paper investigates the impact of time-step size on reinforcement learning (RL) models for sepsis treatment, challenging the conventional 4-hour aggregation. Through empirical experiments comparing 1, 2, 4, and 8-hour time steps, the study found that finer granularities (1 and 2 hours) consistently yield superior and more stable treatment policies, especially when using a static behavior policy. This highlights time-step size as a crucial design choice, advocating for alternatives beyond the established 4-hour setup in offline RL for healthcare.

title: Immunometabolic Gatekeeping: Reconciling Peto's & the T-cell Infiltration Prognostic Paradox
summary: This paper introduces an "immunometabolic gatekeeping" framework, positing that the intrinsic metabolic intensity and waste-handling capacity of healthy tissues fundamentally influence anti-tumor immunity. It suggests that metabolically strenuous tissues can foster immune-exhausting niches even before malignant transformation, thus reconciling paradoxes like high T-cell infiltration with poor prognosis.

title: Symbiotic Brain-Machine Drawing via Visual Brain-Computer Interfaces
summary: This research introduces a novel non-invasive brain-computer interface (BCI) designed for "mind-drawing" by iteratively inferring a subject's internal visual intent. Leveraging steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) from single-channel EEG, the system rapidly reconstructs simple imagined shapes within approximately two minutes. A key finding is that symbiotic human-AI interaction, including integration with stable diffusion models, dramatically increases BCI bit-rates by over five times, enhancing reconstructed mental images into detailed visual representations.

title: RefTr: Recurrent Refinement of Confluent Trajectories for 3D Vascular Tree Centerline Graphs
summary: This paper introduces RefTr, a 3D image-to-graph model designed for generating vascular tree centerlines through recurrent refinement of confluent trajectories. RefTr leverages a Transformer-based Producer-Refiner architecture and a novel non-maximum suppression, achieving superior recall, comparable precision, faster inference, and significantly reduced parameters compared to previous state-of-the-art methods.

title: A statistical framework for comparing epidemic forests
summary: This paper introduces the first statistical framework for robustly comparing epidemic forests, which are collections of plausible transmission trees. The framework utilizes both a chi-square test and permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) to assess the statistical significance of differences between these forests. While both methods achieved perfect specificity for larger forests (100+ trees), PERMANOVA consistently demonstrated superior sensitivity across all tested epidemic and forest sizes, making it a more reliable tool for distinguishing transmission dynamics.

title: Adversarial Multi-Task Learning for Liver Tumor Segmentation, Dynamic Enhancement Regression, and Classification
summary: This paper introduces MTI-Net, an end-to-end adversarial multi-task learning framework for simultaneous liver tumor segmentation, dynamic enhancement regression, and classification from MRI. MTI-Net utilizes Multi-domain Information Entropy Fusion (MdIEF) for dynamic MRI data, a task interaction module for inter-task synergy, and a novel task-driven discriminator (TDD) to capture internal task relationships. Experiments on 238 subjects demonstrate high performance across all tasks, indicating significant potential for clinical assessment of liver tumors.

title: MedROV: Towards Real-Time Open-Vocabulary Detection Across Diverse Medical Imaging Modalities
summary: MedROV introduces the first real-time open-vocabulary object detection (OVOD) model for diverse medical imaging, addressing the limitations of traditional closed-set detectors that cannot identify novel labels. By curating a large-scale dataset, Omnis, employing pseudo-labeling, and leveraging knowledge from foundation models with contrastive learning, MedROV achieves significant performance gains and real-time inference, setting a new benchmark in medical detection.
domains: Diverse Imaging Modalities (e.g., X-ray, CT, MRI, Ultrasound, etc.)

title: The Driver-Blindness Phenomenon: Why Deep Sequence Models Default to Autocorrelation in Blood Glucose Forecasting
summary: Deep sequence models for blood glucose forecasting consistently fail to leverage clinically informative drivers--insulin, meals, and activity--despite well-understood physiological mechanisms. We term this Driver-Blindness and formalize it via $Δ_{\text{drivers}}$, the performance gain of multivaria...

title: Assessing LLMs' Performance: Insights from the Chinese Pharmacist Exam
summary: This study evaluated the performance of ChatGPT-4o and DeepSeek-R1 on 2,306 multiple-choice questions from the Chinese Pharmacist Licensing Examination (2017-2021). DeepSeek-R1 significantly outperformed ChatGPT-4o (90.0% vs. 76.1% accuracy), demonstrating robust alignment with the exam's structural and semantic demands, particularly in foundational and clinical synthesis modules. The findings suggest the promise of domain-specific models for medical assessment but underscore the critical need for human oversight in high-stakes contexts.

title: Real-time 3D Ultrasonic Needle Tracking with a Photoacoustic Beacon
summary: This paper presents a novel interventional ultrasound system designed for simultaneous real-time 3D tracking and B-mode guidance of a core biopsy needle. The system utilizes a photoacoustic beacon embedded in the needle's bevel and a sparse receiver array to determine the needle tip's 3D location via time-of-flight measurements. This innovation provides clinicians with a quantitative 3D visualization of the needle tip superimposed on B-mode images, addressing the limitations of current 2D methods and poor needle visibility in complex tissues.

title: FRAGMENTA: End-to-end Fragmentation-based Generative Model with Agentic Tuning for Drug Lead Optimization
summary: FRAGMENTA introduces an end-to-end framework for drug lead optimization, combining a novel generative model that uses dynamic Q-learning for joint fragmentation and generation with an agentic AI system for expert-driven objective refinement. This approach addresses limitations of small datasets and slow model tuning, demonstrating superior performance in cancer drug discovery by identifying significantly more high-scoring molecules and achieving more effective tuning than traditional human-centric methods.

title: The Text Aphasia Battery (TAB): A Clinically-Grounded Benchmark for Aphasia-Like Deficits in Language Models
summary: This paper introduces the Text Aphasia Battery (TAB), a novel text-only benchmark adapted from the Quick Aphasia Battery (QAB), designed to assess aphasia-like deficits in Large Language Models (LLMs). The TAB comprises four subtests, and the authors validated an automated evaluation protocol using Gemini 2.5 Flash, demonstrating reliability comparable to expert human raters. This work provides a scalable, clinically-grounded framework for analyzing language deficits in artificial intelligence systems.

title: Generative Modeling with Manifold Percolation
summary: This paper introduces a novel framework for generative modeling by reframing the task as disentangling geometric support from probability distributions using Continuum Percolation. It establishes an isomorphism between Random Geometric Graphs and data manifold topology, proposing a "Percolation Shift metric" and a differentiable loss function to effectively mitigate structural pathologies like implicit mode collapse, ultimately achieving models with enhanced diversity, fidelity, and topological expansion.

title: A Physics-Informed Loss Function for Boundary-Consistent and Robust Artery Segmentation in DSA Sequences
summary: This paper introduces a novel Physics-Informed Loss (PIL) function designed to enhance the accuracy and robustness of cerebral artery segmentation in Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) sequences. By modeling boundary interactions as an elastic process inspired by dislocation theory, PIL enforces geometric and physical consistency, leading to smoother contours and structurally coherent vessel predictions. The proposed loss consistently outperforms conventional loss functions across various segmentation architectures and public benchmarks.

title: MTBBench: A Multimodal Sequential Clinical Decision-Making Benchmark in Oncology
summary: MTBBench introduces a novel agentic benchmark simulating Molecular Tumor Board (MTB)-style decision-making in oncology, featuring multimodal and longitudinal data, to address the shortcomings of current LLM evaluation. It reveals that state-of-the-art LLMs struggle with reliability, hallucination, and reasoning from complex, time-resolved data, but an integrated agentic framework with foundation model-based tools can significantly boost their multimodal and longitudinal reasoning performance.

title: Wide Area Surface Dosimetry with Conformal Scintillator Array for External Beam Radiotherapy
summary: This paper introduces a novel wide-area surface dosimetry system for external beam radiotherapy, utilizing a conformable scintillator array combined with stereovision and Cherenkov imaging. The system provides dynamic, spatially resolved dose maps across complex anatomical surfaces, demonstrating high accuracy, linearity, and reproducibility, thereby addressing key limitations of current in vivo dosimetry techniques.
